data.title: [Gtk Pipeline] Bunch of fixes
data.body:
Stuff done:
  • Fixed context menu containing Add menu when selecting multiple files
  • Fixed crash when selecting 3 or more objects of different type
  • Fixed [double click] / [right click > open] not launching default application for the file but instead launching the first possible application for that file type
  • Fixed some annoying errors that are being show in application output on new item dialog
  • Double clicking folder now expands/collapses them

data.title: SpriteBatch can't be initialized on constructor method.
Memory leak in VertexBuffer.GetData and IndexBuffer.GetData
data.body:
The methods VertexBuffer/IndexBuffer.PlatformGetData<T> are pinning the data array using GCHandle.Alloc, but never release the handle. 
- https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/81765ff2f4ce6bced932f87ee62496ffc253cc65/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Vertices/VertexBuffer.DirectX.cs#L88
- https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/81765ff2f4ce6bced932f87ee62496ffc253cc65/MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Vertices/IndexBuffer.DirectX.cs#L86

Other methods (Texture2D.GetData, etc.) seem to be implemented correctly.
I suggest adding a try-finally block to all methods where GCHandle.Alloc is used.

data.title: OS X mpack leverages 3.3.X assemblies
data.body:
When leveraging the built in template for MonoDevelop/Xamarin it utilizes the 3.3.X nuget packages which brings down the 3.3 assemblies; was this intentional?

When setting up my recent tests I had to manually leverage 3.4 assemblies from my project directory tree; but it might be useful to correct the 'installer' so its pointing to the correct stuff.

![osx-artificats-3 4 0455-mpack](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419952/7413898/37fa3852-ef1d-11e4-8bd5-ecb660117c28.png)

data.title: Manual Test Framework
data.body:
We should write a framework for manually run unit tests to augment the existing automated unit test framework.

These manual tests would be specifically for features like audio and input which are most easily validated by people.  The trick would be to make sure the test is quick to do and hard to get wrong.  Some core ideas:
- The test app should be built and distributed as part of the automated build process.
- The tests should execute in a fixed order.
- You must complete one test to move to the next one.
- Should take very little time to complete the tests... less than a few minutes.
- The results should contain very basic machine info.
- The tests should work on all our platforms... including phones.
- Once all the tests are completed it should display the results, spit out a text file, and display a button to copy the results to your clipboard for easy pasting into GitHub.

The tests themselves should be crafted so that the user has to do the least work possible.  We should ask the user to do something... verify the result wasn't an accident by repeating it...  store the result of the test and move on to the next one.  We **should not** depend on the user to judge themselves if the test passed or not.

The framework for this should be a standard MonoGame `Game` with some sort of `TestScreen` class that is overloaded for different tests.  The framework would then just find them via reflection, sort them in some consistent order, and run them recording results.

The usage for these would be in validating PRs.  If a PR changes something that is covered in the manual tests we need people to run thru them on all the target platforms before approval and merge.  We would also run them once before we do a release.

Thoughts?

data.title: OS X installer may need to create /usr/local/bin
data.body:
OS X does not appear to have /usr/local/bin by default, even though it is in the PATH.
http://community.monogame.net/t/os-x-3-4-installer-package-issue/2355
The installer should create the directory if it does not exist and give it the appropriate permissions.

@dellis1972 Are you able to look into this?

data.title: GamePad.GetState() Crash in OS X
data.body:
When spooling up a fresh project utilizing the 3.4.0455 build on OS X (which I acquired from TeamCity here -- http://teamcity.monogame.net/viewLog.html?buildId=6519&buildTypeId=MonoGame_DevelopMac&tab=artifacts) my project returns a null reference exception error -- as does the example project on this line

```
if (GamePad.GetState (PlayerIndex.One) ...
```

Even simplifying to 
    var gamePad = GamePad.GetState (PlayerIndex.One);

causes the executable to crash with a null exception error.

`Unhandled Exception:
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object
  at OpenTK.Input.GamePad.GetState (Int32 index) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePad.PlatformGetState (Int32 index, GamePadDeadZone deadZoneMode) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePad.GetState (PlayerIndex playerIndex, GamePadDeadZone deadZoneMode) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePad.GetState (PlayerIndex playerIndex) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at Toolbox.Game1.Update (Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GameTime gameTime) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0`

Xamarin Studio 5.8.3
Mono 3.12.1
GTK+ 2.24.23
XCode 6.2
OS X 10.9.5

3.3 assemblies worked fine.

Happy to provide any additional details if necessary.

data.title: Cross-platform Random number generator
data.body: This fulfills https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/3772, which requires a random number generator that is consistent over platforms. It contains only one utility function as of yet, `ulong MathHelper.Random.GenerateSeed()`.

data.title: Random number generator
data.body: This fulfills https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/3772, which requires a random number generator that is consistant over platforms. It contains only one utility function as of yet, `ulong MathHelper.Random.GenerateSeed()`.

data.title: Fix bug using SpriteBatch layerDepth on OpenGL
data.body:
Fixes #3750.

OpenGL previously needed this depth fixup, but now that there's a depth fixup at the shader level, this fixup in SpriteBatch isn't needed, and was in fact wrong.

OpenGL can just use the same transform matrix as other platforms.

data.title: Fixing Master Conflicts
data.body: This PR fixes some old changes that were done directly in the master branch and never got back into develop.

data.title: Release 3.4
data.body: This is a merge of the latest develop changes into master for the 3.4 release.

data.title: What is the state of SIMD support?
data.body:
Stable version of the system package is available for BCL:

http://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Numerics.Vectors

MonoGame has expressed a keen interest in past:

https://twitter.com/monogameteam/status/301370937679421440
https://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/248825

But unless I am mistaken the low-performance Vector2 is still being used:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/2d43afcc304bbcc53d45c2f31471192c8b1daa32/MonoGame.Framework/Vector2.cs

On the other hand XNA used some sort of magic to make Vector2 "SIMD-ready":

http://blogs.msdn.com/b/abhinaba/archive/2011/04/10/simd-support-in-netcf.aspx

data.title: Windows 10 Support Pt. 4 - Build 2015 Edition
data.body:
This PR has a bunch of fixes to support the new Windows 10 toolset release at Build 2015 tomorrow.
- Support for fullscreen.
- Dpi scaling fixes.
- Fixed bug with list key up events.

Our Windows 10 support is still in its early stages, but it is closer to fully working now.

data.title: Use VisualStudio coding policy when opening the project from MonoDevelop
Formatting in MathHelper
data.body: While working on the new Random class, I noticed that (since my IDE differentiates) the MathHelper class is poorly indented, with some functions for some reason using only one layer of indentation, and tabs at that. Can I have permission to change the formatting a bit @tomspilman ? I will try to keep it as minimal as possible.

data.title: Added GraphicsMetrics struct
Random For Games
data.body:
The main problem I've run into is that the `Random` on different versions of C# while using the same seeds do not result in the same sequence. This is mainly between Mono and .NET. 

We've also found the stock .NET `Random` is pretty slow. Even when doing integer randomization it under the hood uses doubles:

https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/blob/master/src/mscorlib/src/System/Random.cs#L168

Worse MS can't really change the existing `Random` to fix these problems as it could break existing apps.

Also things like not having a `Random.NextFloat(float min, float max)` makes things inconvenient for game developers.

This all suggests adding our own `Random` that is aimed at game development needs.  Mainly a fast replacement for `Random` with support for all the data types and ranges. We would also provide a helper template method to randomly shuffle elements in a list.
- High efficiency.
- Great distribution.
- Deterministic when you need it.
- Can be totally random when you don't.
- Provide complete set of min/max range functions.
- Drop in replacement for .NET `Random`.
- Full set of unit tests proving the implementation.

Thoughts and suggestions welcome.

data.title: Added few random generation functions.
data.body: I think it is not bad addition. Many developers uses this common random generation algorithm and they are forced to write it itself or using other libraries. So my PR fixed this problem.

data.title: Content.Load issue for Windows Phone 8 template.
data.body:
Hello. I have downloaded the latest version of monogame, from teamcity. Then, I used the Windows Phone 8 template for my game, and tried to load a simple content file. But I get the "Object reference not set to an instance of object" exception for Content.Load line. I tried also to set up another project, but the same.

Here are the exception details:
-       $exception  {System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.PlatformFromStream(GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice, Stream stream)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.FromStream(GraphicsDevice graphicsDevice, Stream stream)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadRawAsset[T](String assetName, String originalAssetName)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadAsset[T](String assetName, Action`1 recordDisposableObject)
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load[T](String assetName)
  at Game13.Game1.LoadContent()
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Initialize()
  at Game13.Game1.Initialize()
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.DoInitialize()
  at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Game.Run(GameRunBehavior runBehavior)
  at MonoGame.Framework.WindowsPhone.SurfaceUpdateHandler.Draw(Device device, DeviceContext context, RenderTargetView renderTargetView)
  at MonoGame.Framework.WindowsPhone.DrawingSurfaceUpdateHandler.DrawingSurfaceContentProvider.GetTexture(Size2F surfaceSize, DrawingSurfaceSynchronizedTexture& synchronizedTexture, RectangleF& textureSubRectangle)
  at SharpDX.Direct3D11.DrawingSurfaceContentProviderShadow.DrawingSurfaceContentProviderVtbl.GetTexture(IntPtr thisPtr, IntPtr surfaceSize, IntPtr synchronizedTexture, IntPtr textureSubRectangle)}  System.Exception {System.NullReferenceException}

EDIT:
Also noticed for Windows Phone 8.1 template, but here its another error:
Additional information: HRESULT: [0x88982F50], Module: [SharpDX.WIC], ApiCode: [WINCODEC_ERR_COMPONENTNOTFOUND/Componentnotfound], Message: The component cannot be found.
